Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Road Zone Effects on Endemic Taiwan Herpetofauna
Award.AbstractNarration:
Expansion of road infrastructure increases connectivity, but also brings ecological consequence. Reptiles and amphibians (herpetofauna) have the highest recorded levels of road mortality and are the most threatened group of terrestrial vertebrate taxa, but road ecology studies are lacking. Due to their spatially complex lifestyles and urgent conservation need, herpetofauna are ideal for studying road zone effects across multiple landscape scales. Additionally, habitat fragmentation due to roads is expected to have especially dramatic impacts in island ecosystems, such as Taiwan, an island with high ecological value and twice the road density of the USA. Due to the high-density road networks and biodiversity, Taiwan is a choice site for research on indirect road zone effects on endemic herpetofauna. Although some research has documented direct effects of roads on wildlife in Taiwan, indirect impacts of road zone landscapes on herpetofauna are unclear. These indirect effects can include creation of landscapes near roads that may attract herpetofauna, subsequently increasing herpetofauna vulnerability to road mortality. This study will be conducted in collaboration with noted Taiwan herpetologist and road ecologist, Dr. Te-En Lin, from the Taiwan Endemic Species Research Institute.

This project will measure indirect effects of road fragmentation on Taiwan's herpetofauna across multiple spatial and ecological scales to quantify impacts of roads on local biodiversity. The hypothesis is that indirect effects of road zone landscapes will cause declines in biodiversity at multiple landscape and ecological scales. There are two predicted findings: 1) since road zones can serve as ecological traps, road-zone landscapes will create attractive, but dangerous habitat for many species of herpetofauna across spatial scales; 2) there will be differing rates of road zone utilization across taxonomic groups due to differing life histories. This project will elucidate unstudied indirect impacts of road fragmentation across endemic and local Taiwan herpetofauna communities. This NSF EAPSI award supports the research of a U.S. graduate student and is funded in collaboration with the Ministry of Science and Technology of Taiwan.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF-EAPSI fellowship offered me an opportunity to engage in a conservation project on an island where human-wildlife conflict occurs at high rates due to the high human population and high biodiversity. During the fellowship, I was able to accomplish daily data collection in the field, engage with local researchers, mentor local students, and plan future collaborations.

After a week of orientation and a few days of setback due to a typhoon, I set-up three study sites around Nantou County, each with multiple survey methods to capture a wide range of native reptiles and amphibians. The sites were fully set after two and a half weeks of the eight-week fellowship. For the remainder of the time I collected data in the field twice a day – once in the morning (8 am – 12 pm) and once in the evening (6 pm – 10 pm), weather permitting. I had a field team of four people, three local female students and myself. Soliciting local students for field assistants was important for the study because their knowledge of the region was paramount to locating field sites, and I was given the opportunity to mentor them in ecological theory and field methodology on an internationally supported project.

The preliminary data collected shows a strong trend that as road density increased, the population size and species abundance decreased, supporting my proposal prediction. I gathered promising data on use of landscapes in differing road densities by diverse taxonomic groups of lizards, frogs, and snakes, and will continue to build this dataset upon return to Taiwan.

I plan to return for a longer period to build on and further research on the EAPSI study. During my fellowship, I forged a strong collaborative relationship with Taiwanese road ecologist, Te-En Lin, a researcher for the Taiwan Endemic Species Research Institute (TESRI). Te-En Lin asked to continue collaborating on my project, and I am enthusiastic about this opportunity to work with TESRI to initiate a nationally supported project in the future. We have planned to add a large citizen science data initiative to my project, which will have multiple advantages: environmental education for citizens, generation of a national data-set across multiple landscapes, large sample sizes in relatively short periods, and government involvement. I will implement a new citizen science initiative with Te-En Lin, who already has a large participatory citizen science network, the Taiwan Roadkill Observation Network (TRON) that we will solicit interest from.

I thoroughly enjoyed researching in Taiwan through the EAPSI fellowship and it has inspired me to continue a collaboration with my host researcher, as well as expand my project and educational reach across the island through mentorship and a citizen science data component. My preliminary findings have already found trends of indirect ecological effects of roads, and will produce results that have immediate applicability to the global problem of ecological consequences of roads, especially for developing island regions with high biodiversity and large populations.
